text: The DNA binding domain of the <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factor is responsible for its B cell - specific activity and binds to a B cell 110-kDa nuclear protein .

Expression studies as well as the use of transgenic animals have demonstrated that the <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factor plays central and specific role in the regulation of mature B cell proliferation and / or differentiation .
Furthermore , it is highly expressed in Burkitt 's lymphoma cells and may participate in the pathogenesis of this disease .

We have therefore investigated the transcriptional activity of <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and its regulation in several human lymphoid cell lines using co-transfection assays and show that <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is transcriptionally active in all the B cell lines studied , but not in T cells .

text: In particular the best responder cell line was the Burkitt 's cell line Namalwa .

The activity of <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in B and not T cells was observed when either an artificial construct or the <extra_id_0> c-MYC <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter was used as a reporter .

Furthermore , the functional domains responsible for DNA binding , transactivation , and negative regulation , previously characterized in a fibroblast context , were found to have similar activity in B cells .
The region of <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> responsible for the B cell specific activity was defined to be the N-terminal 218 amino acids containing the DNA binding domain .

Finally , a 110-kDa protein has been identified in the nuclei of all the B , but not T , cell lines that specifically binds to this <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> N-terminal domain .
We hypothesize that this 110-kDa protein may be a functionally important B cell - specific co-activator of <extra_id_0> A-MYB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
